Unveil the Duality of Retrieval-Augmented Generation: Theoretical Analysis and Practical Solution

Shicheng Xu1,2, Liang Pang1, Huawei Shen1,2, Xueqi Cheng1,211footnotemark: 1
1CAS Key Laboratory of AI Safety,
Institute of Computing Technology,
Chinese Academy of Sciences
2University of Chinese Academy of Sciences
{xushicheng21s,pangliang,shenhuawei,cxq}@ict.ac.cn Â Â Corresponding authors
Abstract

Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) utilizes retrieved texts to enhance large language models (LLMs). However, studies show that RAG is not consistently effective and can even mislead LLMs due to noisy or incorrect retrieved texts. This suggests that RAG possesses a duality including both benefit and detriment. Although many existing methods attempt to address this issue, they lack a theoretical explanation for the duality in RAG. The benefit and detriment within this duality remain a â€œblack boxâ€ that cannot be quantified or compared in an explainable manner. This paper takes the first step in theoretically giving the essential explanation of benefit and detriment in RAG by: (1) decoupling and formalizing them from RAG prediction, (2) approximating the gap between their values by representation similarity and (3) establishing the trade-off mechanism between them, to make them explainable, quantifiable, and comparable. We demonstrate that the distribution difference between retrieved texts and LLMsâ€™ knowledge acts as â€œdouble-edged sword,â€ bringing both benefit and detriment. We also prove that the actual effect of RAG can be predicted at token level. Based on our theory, we propose a practical novel method, X-RAG, which achieves collaborative generation between pure LLM and RAG at token level to preserve benefit and avoid detriment. Experiments in real-world tasks based on LLMs including OPT, LLaMA-2, and Mistral show the effectiveness of our method and support our theoretical results.

1 Introduction

Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) has shown promising performance in enhancing LLMs via integrating retrieved texts Â Xu etÂ al. (2023); Shi etÂ al. (2023); Asai etÂ al. (2023); Ram etÂ al. (2023), which is actually the knowledge fusion between parameters and retrieved texts. However, studies show that this fusion is not consistently effective and can even mislead LLMs due to noisy or incorrect retrieved textsÂ Xu etÂ al. (2023); Ram etÂ al. (2023); Xu etÂ al. (2024a, b); Jin etÂ al. (2024a); Xie etÂ al. (2023); Jin etÂ al. (2024b). This implies that RAG has the duality including both benefit and detriment. Current methods attempt to address this by adding additional modules, prompt engineering, or fine-tuning LLMs.Â Asai etÂ al. (2023); Xu etÂ al. (2023, 2024a); Yoran etÂ al. (2024); Ren etÂ al. (2023); Feng etÂ al. (2023); Mallen etÂ al. (2022); Jiang etÂ al. (2023). Despite these efforts, there remains a lack of a theoretical and essential explanation for the benefit and detriment in RAG that could improve our understanding and find a more fundamental solution.

In this paper, we provide a theoretical explanation for the benefit and detriment in RAG and propose a novel practical method based on our theoretical results (FigureÂ 1). From a theoretical perspective, this paper pioneers in giving the essential explanation of benefit and detriment by: (1) decoupling and formalizing them from RAG prediction, (2) approximating the gap between their values using representation similarity, and (3) establishing the trade-off mechanism between them, to make them explainable, quantifiable, and comparable. Specifically, inspired by previous methods that prove LLMs implicitly perform latent variable inferenceÂ Xie etÂ al. (2021); Wang etÂ al. (2024), we propose to analyze RAG by Latent Variable Model, in which LLMs firstly infer the latent variable and then generate the texts conditioned on the latent variable. In this way, we decouple and formalize the benefit and detriment from RAG prediction as two terms in subtraction. Further derivation based on this shows that: (1) We essentially explain the occurrence of benefit and detriment in RAG. The distribution difference between the retrieved texts and the LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge is â€œdouble-edged swordâ€. The larger distribution difference can provide more out-of-distribution knowledge for LLMs but also runs the risk of misleading them. Consequently, it brings both benefit and detriment. (2) We prove that the actual effect of RAG, which is the trade-off between benefit and detriment, can be predicted at token level (right side in FigureÂ 1 (a)). Specifically, we find benefit and detriment bound the similarity between RAG representation and retrieved representation (Simâ¢(RAG,IR)SimRAGIR\textnormal{Sim}(\textrm{RAG},\textrm{IR})Sim ( RAG , IR )), and the value of benefit minus detriment is positively correlated with this similarity. When benefit is equal to detriment, this similarity is equal to the similarity between RAG representation and pure LLM representation (Simâ¢(RAG,IR)=Simâ¢(RAG,LLM)SimRAGIRSimRAGLLM\textnormal{Sim}(\textrm{RAG},\textrm{IR})=\textnormal{Sim}(\textrm{RAG},% \textrm{LLM})Sim ( RAG , IR ) = Sim ( RAG , LLM )). So the value order between Simâ¢(RAG,IR)SimRAGIR\textnormal{Sim}(\textrm{RAG},\textrm{IR})Sim ( RAG , IR ) and Simâ¢(RAG,LLM)SimRAGLLM\textnormal{Sim}(\textrm{RAG},\textrm{LLM})Sim ( RAG , LLM ) indicates the value order between benefit and detriment in RAG without training.

Based on our theoretical results, we propose a practical novel method called X-RAG that can achieve collaborative generation between pure LLM and RAG at token level to preserve benefit and avoid detriment. In X-RAG, pure LLM and RAG generate the texts in parallel (FigureÂ 1 (b)). At the generation step where LLM and RAG generate the different tokens, X-RAG uses our theoretical results to determine which token will be selected by comparing the values of benefit and detriment brought by RAG to the token. Experimental results in real-world tasks such as Q&A and Long-Form Q&A based on LLMs including OPT, LLaMA-2, and Mistral show the effectiveness of our method and support our theoretical results. Our method does not need any additional modules111Collaborative generation does not need additional modules because it can be executed in parallel of a batch. or training but outperforms baselines that need additional modules and fine-tuning LLMs, which indicates that our theoretical results are essential and fundamental for RAG. The main contributions of this paper are:

âˆ™âˆ™\bulletâˆ™ This paper takes the first step in theoretically giving the essential explanation of benefit and detriment in RAG to make them explainable, quantifiable, and comparable.

âˆ™âˆ™\bulletâˆ™ We prove distribution difference between retrieved texts and LLMsâ€™ knowledge is a â€œdouble-edged swordâ€ that brings both benefit and detriment. Besides, we prove that the actual effect of RAG (i.e., the trade-off between benefit and detriment) can be predicted at token level, which is significant for fine-grained preserving benefit and avoiding detriment in practical applications of RAG.

âˆ™âˆ™\bulletâˆ™ Based on the theoretical results, we propose a practical novel method to enable pure LLM and RAG to collaboratively generate at token level. Experimental results on real-world tasks across different LLMs show the effectiveness of our method and support our theoretical results.

2 Understand the duality of RAG: benefit and detriment

RAG has the duality, although the retrieved texts can provide LLMs with external knowledge (benefit), it also contains the risk of misleading LLMs due to the noise in retrieved texts (detriment). This section aims to theoretically unveil this duality (i.e., benefit and detriment) in RAG. Firstly, we give our definition, analysis perspective and framework for benefit and detriment in RAG. Secondly, we decouple and formalize benefit and detriment from RAG prediction as the two terms in subtraction to make them explainable. Thirdly, which is also the ultimate goal of this paper, we prove that the actual effect of RAG (i.e., the trade-off between benefit and detriment) can be predicted at token level.

2.1 Definition and pre-analysis for benefit and detriment in RAG

Definition. From the perspective of correctness, the relationship between the knowledge generated by pure LLM and the knowledge generated by RAG can be classified into four categories: (1) the knowledge of both is correct, (2) the knowledge of both is wrong, (3) the knowledge of pure LLM is wrong while the knowledge of RAG is correct, (4) the knowledge of pure LLM is correct while the knowledge of RAG is wrong. Since the former two are consistent in correctness, this paper focuses on the latter two and defines (3) as benefit and (4) as detriment.

Distribution difference brings the benefit and detriment. The knowledge pre-trained in LLMs has the boundaryÂ Ren etÂ al. (2023). Retrieved texts bring new knowledge to LLMs and trigger the knowledge distribution difference between retrieved texts and LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge. In this paper, we propose that this distribution difference is a â€œdouble-edged swordâ€, which can be used to essentially explain the occurrence of benefit and detriment in RAG. Assuming that the retrieved texts are perfect, the larger the distribution difference between LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge and retrieved texts, the more out-of-distribution knowledge the retrieved texts can provide to LLMs, and the higher the benefit. However, the retrieved texts are not always perfect and may contain noisy even incorrect information, in this case, distribution difference will mislead the LLM, causing detriment. Therefore, benefit and detriment in RAG are essentially triggered by the distribution difference between LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge and retrieved texts. The following sections will illustrate this point theoretically.

Analysis framework: formalizing RAG as latent variable model. To begin the analysis, inspired by previous studies that prove LLMs implicitly perform latent variable inferenceÂ Xie etÂ al. (2021); Zhang etÂ al. (2023); Wang etÂ al. (2024), we first propose to formalize RAG as the latent variable model. Specifically, given the token sequence x1:iâˆ’1={x1,x2,â€¦â¢xiâˆ’1}subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1x_{1:i-1}=\{x_{1},x_{2},...x_{i-1}\}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } generated from time step 1111 to iâˆ’1ğ‘–1i-1italic_i - 1, from the perspective of the latent variable model, the probability distribution of the token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th step can be described as this:

Latent variable model has been applied in many methods such as LDAÂ Blei etÂ al. (2003). Recent studies prove that in-context learning of LLMs can also be seen as the latent variable model, in which the LLMs sample the concept across the input examplesÂ Xie etÂ al. (2021); Zhang etÂ al. (2023). Inspired by this, we analyse RAG as sampling the Retrieved Concept zâˆ—superscriptğ‘§z^{*}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the input retrieved texts list R={r1,r2,â€¦,rn}ğ‘…subscriptğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘Ÿ2â€¦subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘›R=\{r_{1},r_{2},...,r_{n}\}italic_R = { italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a retrieved passage), and then predicting pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which can be formalized as:

=âˆ«ğ’µâˆ’{zâˆ—}pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1,z)â¢pâ¢(z|R,x1:iâˆ’1)â¢ğ‘‘z+pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1,zâˆ—)â¢pâ¢(zâˆ—|R,x1:iâˆ’1).absentsubscriptğ’µsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘conditionalğ‘§ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1differential-dğ‘§ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘§ğ‘conditionalsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1\displaystyle=\int_{\mathcal{Z}-\{{z}^{*}\}}p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1},z)p(z|R,x_{1:i% -1})\,dz+p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1},z^{*})p(z^{*}|R,x_{1:i-1}).= âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Z - { italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ) italic_p ( italic_z | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_z + italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_p ( italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

EquationÂ 2 describes the knowledge fusion in RAG. The first term is the prediction that marginalizes out all latent concepts except zâˆ—superscriptğ‘§z^{*}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is the knowledge within LLMs. The second term is the prediction that is only conditioned on zâˆ—superscriptğ‘§z^{*}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is the knowledge from retrieved texts.

2.2 Decouple and formalize benefit and detriment

Recapping the view that distribution difference brings both benefit and detriment in RAG we want to illustrate (SectionÂ 2.1), next, we derive the relationship between knowledge fusion and distribution difference from EquationÂ 2 to decouple and formalize the benefit and detriment from RAG prediction. Inspired byÂ Xie etÂ al. (2021), the EquationÂ 2 can be transformed as (detailed proof can be found in AppendixÂ A):

pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1\displaystyle p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =âˆ«ğ’µpâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1,z)â¢pâ¢(z|R,x1:iâˆ’1)â¢ğ‘‘zabsentsubscriptğ’µğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘conditionalğ‘§ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1differential-dğ‘§\displaystyle=\int_{\mathcal{Z}}p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1},z)p(z|R,x_{1:i-1})\,dz= âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ) italic_p ( italic_z | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_d italic_z (3)
âˆâˆ«ğ’µpâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1,z)â¢pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)â¢pâ¢(z)â¢ğ‘‘zproportional-toabsentsubscriptğ’µğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘§differential-dğ‘§\displaystyle\propto\int_{\mathcal{Z}}p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1},z)p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)p(% z)\,dzâˆ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ) italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) italic_p ( italic_z ) italic_d italic_z (4)
=âˆ«ğ’µpâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1,z)â¢expâ¢(râ¢(z))â¢pâ¢(z)â¢ğ‘‘z,râ¢(z)=logâ¢pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|zâˆ—)formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptğ’µğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§expğ‘Ÿğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘§differential-dğ‘§ğ‘Ÿğ‘§logğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘§\displaystyle=\int_{\mathcal{Z}}p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1},z)\textrm{exp}(r(z))p(z)\,% dz,\quad r(z)=\textrm{log}\frac{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)}{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z^{*})}= âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ) exp ( italic_r ( italic_z ) ) italic_p ( italic_z ) italic_d italic_z , italic_r ( italic_z ) = log divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG (5)

Define risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a passage in the retrieved texts list Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, we can get (see detailed proof in AppendixÂ B):

râ¢(z)=logâ¢pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|zâˆ—)ğ‘Ÿğ‘§logğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘§\displaystyle r(z)=\textrm{log}\frac{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)}{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z^{*})}italic_r ( italic_z ) = log divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG â‰ˆlogâ¢âˆi=1nOâ¢(1)â¢pâ¢(ri|z)âˆi=1nOâ¢(1)â¢pâ¢(ri|zâˆ—)absentlogsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‚1ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘§superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‚1ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ‘§\displaystyle\approx\textrm{log}\frac{\prod_{i=1}^{n}O(1)p(r_{i}|z)}{\prod_{i=% 1}^{n}O(1)p(r_{i}|z^{*})}â‰ˆ log divide start_ARG âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG (6)
â†’nâˆ—1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nlâ¢oâ¢gâ¢pâ¢(ri|z)p(ri|zâˆ—)=nâˆ—ğ”¼râˆ¼Prâ¢[lâ¢oâ¢gâ¢pâ¢(ri|z)pâ¢(ri|zâˆ—)]\displaystyle\rightarrow n*\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}log\frac{p(r_{i}|z)}{p(r_{% i}|z*)}=n*\mathbb{E}_{r\sim P_{r}}\left[log\frac{p(r_{i}|z)}{p(r_{i}|z^{*})}\right]â†’ italic_n âˆ— divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l italic_o italic_g divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z âˆ— ) end_ARG = italic_n âˆ— blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_l italic_o italic_g divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ] (7)
âˆpRâ¢(r)â¢logâ¢pâ¢(r|z)pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)=pRâ¢(r)â¢logâ¢pRâ¢(r)pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)âˆ’pRâ¢(r)â¢logâ¢pRâ¢(r)pâ¢(r|z)proportional-toabsentsubscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿlogğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘§ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿlogsubscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿlogsubscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘§\displaystyle\propto p_{R}(r)\textrm{log}\frac{p(r|z)}{p(r|z^{*})}=p_{R}(r)% \textrm{log}\frac{p_{R}(r)}{p(r|z^{*})}-p_{R}(r)\textrm{log}\frac{p_{R}(r)}{p(% r|z)}âˆ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) log divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) log divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) log divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) end_ARG (8)
=âˆ’(KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|z))âŸbenefitâˆ’KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—))âŸdetriment),\displaystyle=-(\underbrace{\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))}_{\textbf{benefit}}-% \underbrace{\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))}_{\textbf{detriment}}),= - ( underâŸ start_ARG KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT benefit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - underâŸ start_ARG KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT detriment end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (9)

pRâ¢(â‹…)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…â‹…p_{R}(\cdot)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( â‹… ) is the distribution of the retrieved texts, pâ¢(â‹…)ğ‘â‹…p(\cdot)italic_p ( â‹… ) is the distribution of the LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge. râ¢(z)ğ‘Ÿğ‘§r(z)italic_r ( italic_z ) is an important term in knowledge fusion because it reflects the proportion between the latent concept from the space of LLMs and from the retrieved texts. Details are in AppendixÂ C.

Discuss the benefit and detriment based on the theoretical results. In EquationÂ 9, the first term is the distribution difference between retrieved texts (pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r )) and LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge (pâ¢(r|z)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘§p(r|z)italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z )) given the concept zğ‘§zitalic_z that is sampled from ğ’µğ’µ\mathcal{Z}caligraphic_Z (full set of latent variables in LLMs). The second term is the distribution difference between the retrieved texts (pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r )) and LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge given the concept zâˆ—superscriptğ‘§z^{*}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is sampled from retrieved texts (pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§p(r|z^{*})italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )). Recapping our definition of benefit and detriment in SectionÂ 2.1, the first term is actually the benefit in RAG, the larger this value is, the more out-of-distribution knowledge the retrieved texts can provide to LLM. Considering that the retrieved texts may contain incorrect information and noise that contradicts the correct knowledge of LLMs, the second term measures this risk and can be seen as the detriment in RAG. It is because pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§p(r|z^{*})italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the prediction made by LLM conditioned on the concept zâˆ—superscriptğ‘§z^{*}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT sampled from the retrieved texts. If external knowledge in the retrieved texts contradicts LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge, pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§p(r|z^{*})italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) will have a gap compared to pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) (the actual distribution of the retrieved texts). Therefore, the difference between pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§p(r|z^{*})italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) primarily stems from the LLMsâ€™ resistance to any external knowledge in the retrieved texts that contradicts LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge. The larger difference indicates the more intense resistance from LLMs, and the more confident the LLMs are in their pre-trained knowledge, which means the greater the potential detriment caused by the retrieved texts. This explains the occurrence mechanism and relationship between benefit and detriment in RAG.

Corollary 1.

Two terms about distribution difference in EquationÂ 9 explain the occurrence mechanism of benefit and detriment respectively. A larger distribution difference not only indicates more out-of-distribution knowledge (benefit) but also implies the LLMsâ€™ resistance to the retrieved texts that contradict the pre-trained knowledge (detriment). Subtraction between benefit and detriment illustrates the â€œdouble-edged swordâ€ trade-off in knowledge fusion of RAG.

2.3 Actual effect of RAG can be predicted at token level

Based on the above analysis, we successfully explain the occurrence of benefit and detriment in RAG from a distribution difference perspective. Besides, we decouple and formalize benefit and detriment as two terms in subtraction. Next, we further discuss the impact of benefit and detriment on the prediction of RAG and find that both benefit and detriment bound the similarity between pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which can serve as an important signal indicating the value order between benefit and detriment at token level. Specifically, recapping the EquationÂ 2 that describes the knowledge fusion in RAG via latent variable model, we derive TheoremÂ 1:

Theorem 1.

Define ğ’Ÿ=âˆ¥p(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)âˆ’pR(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)âˆ¥1\mathcal{D}=\|p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})-p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})\|_{1}caligraphic_D = âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to measure the difference between output distribution of RAG (pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) and the distribution of retrieved texts conditioned on prefix x1:iâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1x_{1:i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )). Both benefit and detriment are important terms of the upper and lower bounds of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, which can be described as:

â€–Î¦â€–1âˆ’2KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—))\displaystyle\|\Phi\|_{1}-\sqrt{2\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))}âˆ¥ roman_Î¦ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - square-root start_ARG 2 KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG â‰¤ğ’Ÿâ‰¤â€–Î¦â€–1+2KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—)),\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{D}\leq\|\Phi\|_{1}+\sqrt{2\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|% p(r|z^{*}))},â‰¤ caligraphic_D â‰¤ âˆ¥ roman_Î¦ âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + square-root start_ARG 2 KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG , (10)
Î¦â‰ˆÎ±â¢âˆ«ğ’µâˆ’{zâˆ—}pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1,z)â¢expÎ¦ğ›¼subscriptğ’µsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§exp\displaystyle\Phi\approx\alpha\int_{\mathcal{Z}-\{{z}^{*}\}}p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1% },z)\textnormal{exp}roman_Î¦ â‰ˆ italic_Î± âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Z - { italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ) exp [âˆ’(KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|z))âŸbenefitâˆ’KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—))âŸdetriment]p(z)dz,\displaystyle\left[-(\underbrace{\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))}_{% \textnormal{{benefit}}}-\underbrace{\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))}_{% \textnormal{{detriment}}}\right]p(z)\,dz,[ - ( underâŸ start_ARG KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT benefit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - underâŸ start_ARG KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT detriment end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] italic_p ( italic_z ) italic_d italic_z ,

in which Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is a constant. Our detailed proof of TheoremÂ 1 can be found in AppendixÂ D.

Theorem 2.

ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is the difference, so 1ğ’Ÿ1ğ’Ÿ\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG can be treated as similarity between pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The result of benefit minus detriment is approximately positively correlated with 1D1ğ·\frac{1}{D}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_D end_ARG:

KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|z))âŸbenefitâˆ’KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—))âŸdetrimentâˆ1ğ’Ÿ.\underbrace{\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))}_{\textnormal{{benefit}}}-% \underbrace{\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))}_{\textnormal{{detriment}}}% \propto\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}.underâŸ start_ARG KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT benefit end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - underâŸ start_ARG KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT detriment end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG . (11)

Our detailed proof of TheoremÂ 2 is in AppendixÂ E. We successfully prove that the actual effect of RAG can be predicted at token level. The gap between values of benefit and detriment in EquationÂ 11 indicates how much greater the benefit is than the detriment, which is the actual effect of RAG. This gap is approximately positively correlated with the representation similarity, which is the value that can be predicted (details in SectionÂ 3). Besides, EquationÂ 11 is derived from the token level prediction (pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )), this shows that the actual effect of RAG can be predicted at token level by 1D1ğ·\frac{1}{D}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_D end_ARG. SectionÂ 3 introduces our detailed method to achieve this in practical applications.

3 X-RAG: Improve RAG based on duality analysis

We aim to improve RAG by retaining tokens whose benefit is greater than detriment, and replacing tokens whose benefit is less than detriment. The key to achieving this is to determine the value order between benefit and detriment at token level. SectionÂ 2.3 shows that the result of benefit minus detriment is approximately positively correlated with 1D1ğ·\frac{1}{D}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_D end_ARG. So the value of 1D1ğ·\frac{1}{D}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_D end_ARG when benefit minus detriment is zero is an important dividing point. A 1D1ğ·\frac{1}{D}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_D end_ARG greater than this value indicates that benefit is greater than detriment, and conversely, the benefit is less than detriment. We derive TheoremÂ 3 to find this dividing point and map the value order between benefit and detriment of token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the relationship between representation similarity that can be calculated in practical applications:

Theorem 3.

Define â„³=âˆ¥p(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)âˆ’p(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)âˆ¥1\mathcal{M}=\|p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})-p(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})\|_{1}caligraphic_M = âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to measure the difference between output distribution of RAG (pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )) and pure LLM (pâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )), so 1â„³1â„³\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG can be treated as the similarity between them. 1ğ’Ÿ=1â„³1ğ’Ÿ1â„³\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}=\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG is the dividing point in which benefit is equal to detriment, and the value order between 1ğ’Ÿ1ğ’Ÿ\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG and 1â„³1â„³\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG can indicate the value order between benefit and detriment as:

J={KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|z))<KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—)), detriment outweighs benefit.ifÂ â¢1ğ’Ÿ<1â„³KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|z))=KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—)), detriment is equal to benefit.ifÂ â¢1ğ’Ÿ=1â„³KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|z))>KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—)), benefit outweighs detriment.ifÂ â¢1ğ’Ÿ>1â„³\displaystyle J=\begin{cases}\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))<\textnormal{KL}% (p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))\text{, detriment outweighs benefit.}&\text{if }\frac{1}% {\mathcal{D}}<\frac{1}{\mathcal{M}}\\ \textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))=\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))\text{,% detriment is equal to benefit.}&\text{if }\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}=\frac{1}{% \mathcal{M}}\\ \textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))>\textnormal{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))\text{,% benefit outweighs detriment.}&\text{if }\frac{1}{\mathcal{D}}>\frac{1}{% \mathcal{M}}\end{cases}italic_J = { start_ROW start_CELL KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) < KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) , detriment outweighs benefit. end_CELL start_CELL if divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) = KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) , detriment is equal to benefit. end_CELL start_CELL if divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) > KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) , benefit outweighs detriment. end_CELL start_CELL if divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_D end_ARG > divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW (12)

Our detailed proof of TheoremÂ 3 can be found in AppendixÂ F. EquationÂ 12 is a novel principle that can measure the value order between benefit and detriment in RAG at token level. It does not rely on additional modules or training but simply compares the similarity. Our X-RAG, a practical novel method that enables LLM and RAG to collaborate at token level for generation to preserve benefit and avoid detriment, is constructed based on this. X-RAG makes pure LLM and RAG generate the texts in parallel at token level. At the generation step where pure LLM and RAG generate the different tokens, X-RAG determines which token will be selected by comparing the values of benefit and detriment brought by RAG to the token according to EquationÂ 12. Specifically, the key terms of EquationÂ 12 consist of three parts: (1) pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) can be directly obtained from the prediction of RAG; (2) pâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) can be directly obtained from the prediction of pure LLM; (3) however, the distribution of retrieved texts conditioned on the prefix x1:iâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1x_{1:i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), is hard to directly obtained, which is the main challenge that the following SectionÂ 3.1 aims to solve.

3.1 Distribution prediction for retrieved texts

Based on our theoretical analysis in sectionÂ 2.2 and the detailed proof in AppendixÂ G, we find that:

Corollary 2.

RAG is unsupervised In-context Learning that fuses the distribution from retrieved texts with LLMsâ€™ pre-trained distribution. The distribution of retrieved passage rrritalic_r in RAG (i.e., pRâ¢(r)subscriptpRrp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r )) can serve as the unsupervised learning signal for LLMs learning from context, even without explicit input-output supervision like demonstrations in traditional In-context learning.

Therefore, an intuitive idea is that the distribution pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) can be approximately predicted by capturing the signal from the retrieved texts in knowledge fusion. The main challenges to achieving it are: (1) how to determine where knowledge fusion occurs (2) how to capture the signal that fused from retrieved texts and transform it to distribution pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). To address these, we explore the operating mechanism of RAG and propose a novel method to dynamically determine the layers where knowledge fusion occurs and use the signal from retrieved texts in these layers as pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Exploring the mechanism of RAG. We find that the mechanism of RAG can be decomposed into two parts. The first is text matching, which means extracting information relevant to the generation of xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the retrieved texts Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. The second is knowledge fusion, which means fusing the knowledge obtained from the retrieved texts with the knowledge in LLMsâ€™ parameters. LLMs perform the former in the middle layers and perform the latter in the deep layers. We present these findings in detail with experiments based on LLaMA-2-7B with 32 layers and Natural Question dataset.

For text matching, we quantify the relevance of the information in the retrieved texts to the generation of token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given x1:iâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1x_{1:i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by attention score between token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the tokens in the retrieved texts Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. We explore how the sum of attention scores from token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to tokens in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R changes with the layer. The blue line in FigureÂ 2 shows that: (1) The value increases sharply to a peak in shallow layers (00-5555), which is mainly because LLMs capture the low-level lexical and syntactic information on the entire inputÂ Tenney etÂ al. (2019). (2) The value first decreases and then increases to a maximum point in middle layers (5555-23232323), which is mainly because LLMs select the semantic information that can be used to generate xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Rğ‘…Ritalic_R and complete this selection at the maximum point. (3) The value decreases after the maximum point in deep layers (24242424-32323232). It is because, at this time, LLMs use the knowledge selected at the maximum point for knowledge fusion to predict xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the attention shifts from Rğ‘…Ritalic_R to prefix x1:iâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1x_{1:i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

For knowledge fusion, since the occurrence of knowledge fusion is often accompanied by a change in word distribution, we represent the intensity of knowledge fusion by measuring the change in word distribution between layers.Â Chuang etÂ al. (2023); Schuster etÂ al. (2022) prove the language heads can be directly applied to the hidden states of middle layers, so we propose to obtain the word distribution of hidden states in each layer by language heads Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• as Ï•â¢(hil)italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘™\phi(h_{i}^{l})italic_Ï• ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), in which hilsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘™h_{i}^{l}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the hidden states for token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the lğ‘™litalic_l-th layer. Then we can measure the word distribution change in the lğ‘™litalic_l-th layer by calculating the Jensen-Shannon Divergence (JSD) between Ï•â¢(hilâˆ’1)italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘™1\phi(h_{i}^{l-1})italic_Ï• ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and Ï•â¢(hil)italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘™\phi(h_{i}^{l})italic_Ï• ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) as: C=JSDâ¢(Ï•â¢(hilâˆ’1)âˆ¥Ï•â¢(hil))ğ¶JSDconditionalitalic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘™1italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘™C=\textrm{JSD}(\phi(h_{i}^{l-1})\|\phi(h_{i}^{l}))italic_C = JSD ( italic_Ï• ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ italic_Ï• ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ). We quantify the intensity of LLM fusing the knowledge from retrieved texts by comparing the difference in Cğ¶Citalic_C of the same layer between pure LLM and RAG, which can be described as:

Dl=|JSD(Ï•(h~ilâˆ’1)âˆ¥Ï•(h~il))âˆ’JSD(Ï•(hilâˆ’1)âˆ¥Ï•(hil))|,\displaystyle D^{l}=|\textrm{JSD}(\phi(\tilde{h}_{i}^{l-1})\|\phi(\tilde{h}_{i% }^{l}))-\textrm{JSD}(\phi(h_{i}^{l-1})\|\phi(h_{i}^{l}))|,italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = | JSD ( italic_Ï• ( over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ italic_Ï• ( over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) - JSD ( italic_Ï• ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ italic_Ï• ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) | , (13)

in which h~ilâˆ’1superscriptsubscript~â„ğ‘–ğ‘™1\tilde{h}_{i}^{l-1}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and h~ilsuperscriptsubscript~â„ğ‘–ğ‘™\tilde{h}_{i}^{l}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are from RAG, hilâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘™1h_{i}^{l-1}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and hilsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘™h_{i}^{l}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are from pure LLM. The yellow line in FigureÂ 2 shows Dlsuperscriptğ·ğ‘™D^{l}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is very small in the shallow and middle layers (00-23232323) and rises sharply in the deep layers (24242424-32323232). This suggests that knowledge fusion occurs in deep layers.

The above two results indicate that: When performing RAG, LLMs first perform text matching in the middle layers, extracting relevant knowledge from the retrieved texts. As the depth increases, the matching becomes more and more accurate, and it reaches a turning point. In the deep layers after this turning point, LLMs instead carry out knowledge fusion, and the attention shifts from Rğ‘…Ritalic_R to x1:iâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1x_{1:i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Knowledge used for fusion comes from the matching information around the turning point (because matching decreases after the turning point). Recapping two challenges at the beginning of SectionÂ 3.1, for the first challenge, we can locate the layer where knowledge fusion starts by detecting the turning point in FigureÂ 2. For the second challenge, we can use the matching information in the layer where knowledge fusion starts to approximate the distribution pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Dynamically locate the layer where knowledge fusion starts. For pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the layer where knowledge fusion starts can be located by detecting the turning point in FigureÂ 2. Specifically, we use fâ¢(l)ğ‘“ğ‘™f(l)italic_f ( italic_l ) to denote the attention score for xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT varies with layer lğ‘™litalic_l and gâ¢(l)ğ‘”ğ‘™g(l)italic_g ( italic_l ) to denote the difference of word distribution change in EquationÂ 13 varies with layer lğ‘™litalic_l. The layer where knowledge fusion starts is:

lâˆ—=âŒŠ12â¢(argâ¡maxlâ¡fâ¢(l)+minâ¡{l:gâ¢(l)>a})âŒ‹.superscriptğ‘™12subscriptğ‘™ğ‘“ğ‘™:ğ‘™ğ‘”ğ‘™ğ‘\displaystyle l^{*}=\lfloor\frac{1}{2}(\arg\max_{l}f(l)+\min\{l:g(l)>a\})\rfloor.italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âŒŠ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_l ) + roman_min { italic_l : italic_g ( italic_l ) > italic_a } ) âŒ‹ . (14)

The first term is the lğ‘™litalic_l that maximizes fâ¢(l)ğ‘“ğ‘™f(l)italic_f ( italic_l ), which is the third turning point in the blue line of FigureÂ 2. The second term means the minimum lğ‘™litalic_l value for which gâ¢(l)ğ‘”ğ‘™g(l)italic_g ( italic_l ) is greater than ağ‘aitalic_a (hyperparameter, can be set to 5e-7 according to our statistics), which is the turning point in the yellow line of FigureÂ 2. We take the average of the two values and round down as the layer lâˆ—superscriptğ‘™l^{*}italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where knowledge fusion starts.

Matching as distribution. The matching information between R=[râ¢t1,râ¢t2,â€¦,râ¢tm]ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡2â€¦ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šR=[rt_{1},rt_{2},...,rt_{m}]italic_R = [ italic_r italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_r italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] (râ¢tğ‘Ÿğ‘¡rtitalic_r italic_t is the token in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R) and token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT around turning point can be used to approximate the distribution pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the retrieved texts Rğ‘…Ritalic_R conditioned on x1:iâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1x_{1:i-1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at the lâˆ—superscriptğ‘™l^{*}italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-th layer. The matching information consists of two parts, one is the attention score, which can measure the matching between retrieved tokens and current token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at the hidden state level. The other is the similarity of word embeddings, which can measure the matching between retrieved tokens and current token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at the word distribution level:

Aâ¢tâ¢tğ´ğ‘¡ğ‘¡\displaystyle Attitalic_A italic_t italic_t =softmaxâ¢((h~ilâˆ—â¢Wq)â¢(h~1:mlâˆ—â¢Wk)Tdk),Wâ¢oâ¢râ¢dâ¢Sâ¢iâ¢m=softmaxâ¢((xilâ€²âˆ’lâˆ—â¢A)â¢(râ¢t1:mlâˆ—â¢A)T),formulae-sequenceabsentsoftmaxsuperscriptsubscript~â„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘™subscriptğ‘Šğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript~â„:1ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘™subscriptğ‘Šğ‘˜ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜ğ‘Šğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘‘ğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘šsoftmaxsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğ‘™â€²superscriptğ‘™ğ´superscriptğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡:1ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘™ğ´ğ‘‡\displaystyle=\textrm{softmax}\left(\frac{(\tilde{h}_{i}^{l^{*}}W_{q})(\tilde{% h}_{1:m}^{l^{*}}W_{k})^{T}}{\sqrt{d_{k}}}\right),WordSim=\textrm{softmax}\left% ((x_{i}^{l^{\prime}-l^{*}}A)(rt_{1:m}^{l^{*}}A)^{T}\right),= softmax ( divide start_ARG ( over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ) , italic_W italic_o italic_r italic_d italic_S italic_i italic_m = softmax ( ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A ) ( italic_r italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (15)

Wqsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘W_{q}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Wksubscriptğ‘Šğ‘˜W_{k}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are matrices in attentionÂ Vaswani etÂ al. (2017), h~ilâˆ—superscriptsubscript~â„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘™\tilde{h}_{i}^{l^{*}}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the hidden state of token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and h~1:mlâˆ—superscriptsubscript~â„:1ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘™\tilde{h}_{1:m}^{l^{*}}over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are hidden states of Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. Ağ´Aitalic_A is word embedding matrix in LLMs, xilâ€²âˆ’lâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğ‘™â€²superscriptğ‘™x_{i}^{l^{\prime}-l^{*}}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the token with the largest logits increase in word distribution from layer lâˆ—superscriptğ‘™l^{*}italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the final layer lâ€²superscriptğ‘™â€²l^{\prime}italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, râ¢t1:mlâˆ—ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¡:1ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘™rt_{1:m}^{l^{*}}italic_r italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are tokens in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is:

pR(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)=softmax(AttâŠ™WordSim),âŠ™Â is element-wise multiplication.\displaystyle p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})=\textrm{softmax}\left(Att\odot WordSim% \right),\odot\textnormal{ is element-wise multiplication.}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = softmax ( italic_A italic_t italic_t âŠ™ italic_W italic_o italic_r italic_d italic_S italic_i italic_m ) , âŠ™ is element-wise multiplication. (16)

3.2 Token-Level comparison between benefit and detriment

EquationÂ 12 shows that the relationship between Simâ¢(pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1),pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1))Simğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1\textnormal{Sim}(p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1}),p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1}))Sim ( italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) and Simâ¢(pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1),pâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1))Simğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1\textnormal{Sim}(p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1}),p(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1}))Sim ( italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) indicates the value order between benefit and detriment (Simâ¢(â‹…,â‹…)Simâ‹…â‹…\textnormal{Sim}(\cdot,\cdot)Sim ( â‹… , â‹… ) is the similarity). We propose to use the token semantics as the representation for pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and pâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and use cosine to compute the similarity. It not only follows the principle of EquationÂ 12 but also takes into account the semantic similarity, which is more robust in practical applications. Specifically, we use word embedding matrix of LLMs to calculate the weighted word embedding for pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) as ğ°Râ¢Aâ¢G=1âˆ‘pâ€²â¢âˆ‘(pâ€²,ğ°)âˆˆğ•pâ€²â¢ğ°subscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ´ğº1superscriptğ‘â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ°ğ•superscriptğ‘â€²ğ°\mathbf{w}_{RAG}=\frac{1}{\sum p^{\prime}}\sum_{(p^{\prime},\mathbf{w})\in% \mathbb{V}}p^{\prime}\mathbf{w}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R italic_A italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_w ) âˆˆ blackboard_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_w, for each token in vocabulary ğ•ğ•\mathbb{V}blackboard_V, pâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²p^{\prime}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is its logits from pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and ğ°ğ°\mathbf{w}bold_w is its word embedding. We can also use this to get the weighted word embedding ğ°Lâ¢Lâ¢Msubscriptğ°ğ¿ğ¿ğ‘€\mathbf{w}_{LLM}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L italic_L italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for pâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and ğ°Iâ¢Rsubscriptğ°ğ¼ğ‘…\mathbf{w}_{IR}bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The similarity between them can be calculated via cosine similarity as:

Simâ¢(pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1),pRâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1))Simğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1\displaystyle\textnormal{Sim}(p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1}),p_{R}(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1}))Sim ( italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) =cosâ¢(ğ°Râ¢Aâ¢G,ğ°Iâ¢R)absentcossubscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ´ğºsubscriptğ°ğ¼ğ‘…\displaystyle=\textrm{cos}(\mathbf{w}_{RAG},\mathbf{w}_{IR})= cos ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R italic_A italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (17)
Simâ¢(pâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1),pâ¢(xi|x1:iâˆ’1))Simğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1\displaystyle\textnormal{Sim}(p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1}),p(x_{i}|x_{1:i-1}))Sim ( italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) =cosâ¢(ğ°Râ¢Aâ¢G,ğ°Lâ¢Lâ¢M)absentcossubscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ´ğºsubscriptğ°ğ¿ğ¿ğ‘€\displaystyle=\textrm{cos}(\mathbf{w}_{RAG},\mathbf{w}_{LLM})= cos ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R italic_A italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L italic_L italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (18)

Combining our theoretical analysis of TheoremÂ 1,Â 2 andÂ 3, we can derive this principle to determine the value order between benefit and detriment brought by RAG to the token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in practical applications:

s={benefit winifÂ cosâ¢(ğ°Râ¢Aâ¢G,ğ°Iâ¢R)â‰¥cosâ¢(ğ°Râ¢Aâ¢G,ğ°Lâ¢Lâ¢M),detriment winifÂ cosâ¢(ğ°Râ¢Aâ¢G,ğ°Iâ¢R)<cosâ¢(ğ°Râ¢Aâ¢G,ğ°Lâ¢Lâ¢M),ğ‘ casesbenefit winifÂ cossubscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ´ğºsubscriptğ°ğ¼ğ‘…cossubscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ´ğºsubscriptğ°ğ¿ğ¿ğ‘€detriment winifÂ cossubscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ´ğºsubscriptğ°ğ¼ğ‘…cossubscriptğ°ğ‘…ğ´ğºsubscriptğ°ğ¿ğ¿ğ‘€s=\begin{cases}{\color[rgb]{0.0,0.69,0.0}\textrm{benefit win}}&\text{if }% \textrm{cos}(\mathbf{w}_{RAG},\mathbf{w}_{IR})\geq\textrm{cos}(\mathbf{w}_{RAG% },\mathbf{w}_{LLM}),\\ {\color[rgb]{1,0,0}\textrm{detriment win}}&\text{if }\textrm{cos}(\mathbf{w}_{% RAG},\mathbf{w}_{IR})<\textrm{cos}(\mathbf{w}_{RAG},\mathbf{w}_{LLM}),\end{cases}italic_s = { start_ROW start_CELL benefit win end_CELL start_CELL if roman_cos ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R italic_A italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ cos ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R italic_A italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L italic_L italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL detriment win end_CELL start_CELL if roman_cos ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R italic_A italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < cos ( bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R italic_A italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L italic_L italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , end_CELL end_ROW (19)

4 Experiments

4.1 Experimental details

Experimental setup, metrics, and baselines. The core of our X-RAG is determining the value order between benefit and detriment at token level. This can be viewed as a binary classification task to determine whether benefit is greater than detriment or not. Therefore, a primary experiment is to evaluate this binary classification task at token level (details can be found in SectionÂ 4.2). We use popular metrics for binary classification tasks such as AUC and F1. This task can also be viewed as predicting the correctness of the generated tokens. Therefore, baselines for this are the methods that detect the LLMsâ€™ hallucination. We use these baselines to determine the value order between benefit and detriment by comparing the degree of hallucination at token level between RAG and pure LLM (details in AppendixÂ H.1). Baselines include: (1) Logprobs-basedÂ Kuhn etÂ al. (2023), we use the value order between top-1 log-probability of the tokens output by pure LLM and RAG to determine the value order between benefit and detriment. (2) Uncertainty-based, we use Length-normalized EntropyÂ Malinin and Gales (2020) to measure the uncertainty of the tokens and compare it between pure LLM and RAG. (3) Consistency-based, we run LLMs multiple times and calculate consistency scores among multiple answers using Lexical and Semantic SimilarityÂ Lin etÂ al. (2022); Chen etÂ al. (2024) and compare scores between pure LLM and RAG. Another experiment is in a practical autoregressive generation setting for open-domain Q&A given retrieved texts with different qualities, it aims to evaluate the robustness of RAG methods in practical usage. We use Cover-EMÂ Rosset etÂ al. (2020) that indicates the accuracy in Q&A as the metric. Baselines include the methods that use additional modules to filter irrelevant passages (NLI+RAGÂ Yoran etÂ al. (2024)) or as action triggers (CRAGÂ Yan etÂ al. (2024)), fine-tune more robust LLMs for RAG (RetRobustÂ Yoran etÂ al. (2024) and INFO-RAGÂ Xu etÂ al. (2024a)) and fine-tune LLMs to dynamically retrieve and critique retrieved texts (Self-RAGÂ Asai etÂ al. (2023)).

Datasets. For the token level binary classification task in the primary experiment, we use three long-form generation tasks including long-form Q&A (ASQAÂ Stelmakh etÂ al. (2023)), people biographies generation (BioÂ Min etÂ al. (2023)) and language modeling (Wikitext103Â Merity etÂ al. (2016)) and one short-form task includes Q&A (Natural QuestionsÂ Kwiatkowski etÂ al. (2019)). For the second experiment, since long-form tasks are not conducive to objectively and accurately evaluating the factual correctness of the answers, we use three short-form Q&A tasks including WebQuestions (WebQ)Â Berant etÂ al. (2013), TriviaQAÂ Joshi etÂ al. (2017) and SQuAD v1.1Â Rajpurkar etÂ al. (2016).

Implementation details. As for retrieval in RAG, we followÂ Xu etÂ al. (2023) to use ColBERTv2Â Santhanam etÂ al. (2021), an excellent generalizable model as the retriever, and use Wikipedia consisting of 21,015,324 passagesÂ Karpukhin etÂ al. (2020) as retrieval database. All baselines and X-RAG share the same retrieval setup and input. We use OPT-6.7B, LLaMA-2-7B, and Mistral-7B-v0.1 as LLMs in the primary experiment and use greedy-decoding strategy for generation. More details of X-RAG and baselines are in AppendixÂ H.

4.2 Experimental results

Primary experiment. TableÂ 1 shows that our X-RAG achieves better performance in determining the value order between benefit and detriment at token level in RAG than baselines across different tasks and LLMs. Baselines determine the value order by detecting the degree of hallucination while our X-RAG can directly compare the benefit and detriment based on our theoretical analysis, which is more fundamental so it performs better. In this experiment, we construct the test sample by selecting the token ağ‘aitalic_a generated by RAG that is different from the token bğ‘bitalic_b generated by pure LLM given the same and accurate prefix (Teacher-Forcing). If the token of RAG (ağ‘aitalic_a) is correct and the token of pure LLM (bğ‘bitalic_b) is wrong, the label is 1111 means that the benefit is greater than the detriment. Otherwise, the detriment is greater than the benefit and the label is 00. We use this principle to traverse the second half of the tokens of each sample in the entire dataset to construct the test dataset.

Experiment on Open-domain Q&A. This experiment is under the practical autoregressive generation setting for open-domain Q&A. TableÂ 2 shows that in RAG given the retrieved texts with various qualities, our X-RAG does not need any additional modules or training and outperforms the strong baselines that need additional filters or training LLMs. This means our X-RAG achieves a better trade-off between benefit and detriment in RAG, avoiding detriment while securing benefit. It is because our theoretical analysis helps us propose a more fundamental method in measuring value order between benefit and detriment at token level. Baselines do not have theoretical support, so they require more additional overhead. In this experiment, we adjust the radio of irrelevant passages in the retrieved passage list from 0%percent00\%0 % to 100%percent100100\%100 %, which can simulate the degree of noise in the retrieved texts. Since Open-domain Q&A is a short-form task, we calculate the accuracy by judging whether the ground truth appears exactly in the generated texts (Cover-EMÂ Rosset etÂ al. (2020)). LLM in this is LLaMA-2-7B.

Case study. FigureÂ 4 in AppendixÂ I intuitively shows the collaborative generation between pure LLM and RAG in our X-RAG in open-domain Q&A. X-RAG is effective to preserve benefit and avoid detriment at token level by dynamically selecting suitable tokens among pure LLM and RAG.

Ablation study.

FigureÂ 3 shows the effectiveness of our dynamic layer selection strategy in EquationÂ 14 and supports our finding that RAG performs matching in middle layers. FigureÂ 3 shows the AUC when lâˆ—superscriptğ‘™l^{*}italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in EquationÂ 14 is set as a fixed value from 00 to 32323232. Our dynamic layer selection strategy (dashed line) is always better than any fixed layers (solid line). Besides, AUC is higher in middle layers, which supports that RAG performs matching in middle layers and the knowledge in retrieved texts is extracted in the turning point. After the turning point, LLMs instead perform knowledge fusion, the matching cannot reflect the distribution of retrieved texts, so AUC decreases.

5 Related work

Robust RAG. To make LLMs robust in RAG to avoid the detriment caused from noisy in retrieved texts, some methods use additional modules to filter out irrelevant documentsÂ Yoran etÂ al. (2024); Yan etÂ al. (2024). Some methods train LLMs to make them robust to noisy in retrieved textsÂ Xu etÂ al. (2024a); Yoran etÂ al. (2024). Some methods let LLMs dynamically determine whether the query needs RAGÂ Asai etÂ al. (2023); Xu etÂ al. (2023); Ren etÂ al. (2023); Feng etÂ al. (2023); Mallen etÂ al. (2022); Jiang etÂ al. (2023). All the previous works solve the contradiction between benefit and detriment in RAG from the perspective of application but lacking essential and theoretical analysis, which limits the understanding and cannot find the fundamental method to solve it. Therefore, they rely on additional modules or fine-tuning LLMs. Our paper explains the benefit and detriment in RAG by theoretical analysis and proposes a novel method to preserve benefit while avoiding detriment without any additional modules or training.

Theoretical analysis of ICL. Our paper is inspired by theoretical analysis of ICL. Some works explain ICL as one-step gradient descentÂ VonÂ Oswald etÂ al. (2023); AkyÃ¼rek etÂ al. (2022); Dai etÂ al. (2022). Besides, there are other explanations of ICL such as Bayes inferecneÂ Xie etÂ al. (2021), Bayes model averagingÂ Zhang etÂ al. (2023), leaning topic structureÂ Li etÂ al. (2023) and kernel regressionÂ Han etÂ al. (2023). They focus on explaining why ICL occurs. Our contribution lies in analyzing the benefit and detriment in RAG and proposing a practical method to apply our theoretical results.

6 Conclusions and Discussion

This paper provides the essential understanding of benefit and detriment in RAG to make them explainable, quantifiable, and comparable. We theoretically elucidate that the distribution difference between retrieved texts and LLMsâ€™ pre-trained knowledge is â€œdouble-edged sword" in RAG that brings both benefit and detriment. We prove that the actual effect of RAG can be predicted at token level by representation similarity. Based on our theoretical results, we propose a practical novel method that enables pure LLM and RAG to collaborate at token level, gaining benefit while avoiding detriment. Experiments show the effectiveness of our method and support our theoretical results. Limitations and Societal Impact: The main limitation of this paper is that due to immense resource cost, we do not evaluate our method on LLMs with 33B and 65B scales. Our paper deepens societyâ€™s understanding of LLMsâ€™ usage of external retrieved knowledge through theoretical analysis. After careful consideration, we believe that our paper does not have any potential negative societal impact.

Appendix A Proof for EquationÂ 5

Proof.

The transformation is motivated byÂ Xie etÂ al. [2021] and we apply it to the analysis of RAG:

Appendix B Proof for EquationÂ 6

Proof.

For pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) in râ¢(z)=logâ¢pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|zâˆ—)ğ‘Ÿğ‘§logğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘§r(z)=\textrm{log}\frac{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)}{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z^{*})}italic_r ( italic_z ) = log divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG, we can make further derivation as:

pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)=pâ¢(x1:iâˆ’1|R,z)â¢pâ¢(R|z)ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘…ğ‘§ğ‘conditionalğ‘…ğ‘§\displaystyle p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)=p(x_{1:i-1}|R,z)p(R|z)italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) = italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_z ) italic_p ( italic_R | italic_z ) (25)

According to the definition of latent variable model in the analysis of in-context learning fromÂ Xie etÂ al. [2021] that views the latent variable inference as Hidden Markov Model (HMM) and the latent concept zğ‘§zitalic_z determines the transition probability matrix in HMM hidden states hâ„hitalic_h, we can get the following derivations :

râ¢(z)ğ‘Ÿğ‘§\displaystyle r(z)italic_r ( italic_z ) =logâ¢pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|zâˆ—)absentlogğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘§\displaystyle=\textrm{log}\frac{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)}{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z^{*})}= log divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG (27)

(28)

Based on previous workÂ Xie etÂ al. [2021], Zhang etÂ al. [2023], we make the following assumptions that:

Assumption 1.

All tokens can be predicted, which means that for every token xğ‘¥xitalic_x, there is some hidden state hâ„hitalic_h lower bounds it that pâ¢(x|h,zâˆ—)>c1>0ğ‘conditionalğ‘¥â„superscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘10p(x|h,z^{*})>c_{1}>0italic_p ( italic_x | italic_h , italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) > italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.

Assumption 2.

Delimiter is an important distinguishing signal between each passage rğ‘Ÿritalic_r in the retrieved texts Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. For any delimiter hidden state hdsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘h^{d}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and other hidden state hâ„hitalic_h, there are upper and lower bounds on the transition probability from hâ„hitalic_h to hdsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘h^{d}italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: 0â‰¤c2â‰¤pâ¢(hd|h,z)â‰¤c30subscriptğ‘2ğ‘conditionalsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„ğ‘§subscriptğ‘30\leq c_{2}\leq p(h^{d}|h,z)\leq c_{3}0 â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_p ( italic_h start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_h , italic_z ) â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Then we can get:
