âˆâˆ«ğ’µpâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1,z)â¢pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)â¢pâ¢(z)â¢ğ‘‘zproportional-toabsentsubscriptğ’µğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘§differential-dğ‘§\displaystyle\propto\int_{\mathcal{Z}}p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1},z)p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)p(% z)\,dzâˆ âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ) italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) italic_p ( italic_z ) italic_d italic_z (105)
=âˆ«ğ’µpâ¢(xi|R,x1:iâˆ’1,z)â¢expâ¢(râ¢(z))â¢pâ¢(z)â¢ğ‘‘z,râ¢(z)=logâ¢pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|zâˆ—)formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptğ’µğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘…subscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§expğ‘Ÿğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘§differential-dğ‘§ğ‘Ÿğ‘§logğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘§\displaystyle=\int_{\mathcal{Z}}p(x_{i}|R,x_{1:i-1},z)\textrm{exp}(r(z))p(z)\,% dz,\quad r(z)=\textrm{log}\frac{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)}{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z^{*})}= âˆ« start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_z ) exp ( italic_r ( italic_z ) ) italic_p ( italic_z ) italic_d italic_z , italic_r ( italic_z ) = log divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG (106)
râ¢(z)=logâ¢pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|z)pâ¢(R,x1:iâˆ’1|zâˆ—)ğ‘Ÿğ‘§logğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘…conditionalsubscriptğ‘¥:1ğ‘–1superscriptğ‘§\displaystyle r(z)=\textrm{log}\frac{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z)}{p(R,x_{1:i-1}|z^{*})}italic_r ( italic_z ) = log divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_R , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : italic_i - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG â‰ˆlogâ¢âˆi=1nOâ¢(1)â¢pâ¢(ri|z)âˆi=1nOâ¢(1)â¢pâ¢(ri|zâˆ—)absentlogsuperscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‚1ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘§superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‚1ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–superscriptğ‘§\displaystyle\approx\textrm{log}\frac{\prod_{i=1}^{n}O(1)p(r_{i}|z)}{\prod_{i=% 1}^{n}O(1)p(r_{i}|z^{*})}â‰ˆ log divide start_ARG âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( 1 ) italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG (107)
â†’Oâ¢(1)+nâˆ—1nâ¢âˆ‘i=1nlâ¢oâ¢gâ¢pâ¢(ri|z)p(ri|zâˆ—)=Oâ¢(1)+nâˆ—ğ”¼râˆ¼Prâ¢[lâ¢oâ¢gâ¢pâ¢(ri|z)pâ¢(ri|zâˆ—)]\displaystyle\rightarrow O(1)+n*\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}log\frac{p(r_{i}|z)}{% p(r_{i}|z*)}=O(1)+n*\mathbb{E}_{r\sim P_{r}}\left[log\frac{p(r_{i}|z)}{p(r_{i}% |z^{*})}\right]â†’ italic_O ( 1 ) + italic_n âˆ— divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l italic_o italic_g divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z âˆ— ) end_ARG = italic_O ( 1 ) + italic_n âˆ— blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r âˆ¼ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_l italic_o italic_g divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ] (108)
âˆpRâ¢(r)â¢logâ¢pâ¢(r|z)pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)=pRâ¢(r)â¢logâ¢pRâ¢(r)pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)âˆ’pRâ¢(r)â¢logâ¢pRâ¢(r)pâ¢(r|z)proportional-toabsentsubscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿlogğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘§ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿlogsubscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿlogsubscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘§\displaystyle\propto p_{R}(r)\textrm{log}\frac{p(r|z)}{p(r|z^{*})}=p_{R}(r)% \textrm{log}\frac{p_{R}(r)}{p(r|z^{*})}-p_{R}(r)\textrm{log}\frac{p_{R}(r)}{p(% r|z)}âˆ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) log divide start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) log divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) log divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) end_ARG (109)
=âˆ’(KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|z))âˆ’KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—))),\displaystyle=-(\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z))-\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*}))),= - ( KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) ) - KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) , (110)

We explain EquationÂ 110 from the perspective of the loss function in gradient descent to explain the learning from retrieved texts of LLMs in RAG. pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) is the distribution of retrieved texts and it can serve as ground truth distribution in loss functions. pâ¢(r|z)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘§p(r|z)italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) and pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§p(r|z^{*})italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are distribution estimated by LLMs. Two KL-divergence between ground truth distribution pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) and estimated distribution pâ¢(r|z)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘§p(r|z)italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z ) and pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§p(r|z^{*})italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) respectively are loss functions. rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is the retrieved passage that invariant in generation process, so what contributes to the change of loss function is sampling more and more accurate retrieved concept zâˆ—superscriptğ‘§z^{*}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the retrieved texts. So KL(pR(r)âˆ¥p(r|zâˆ—)\text{KL}(p_{R}(r)\|p(r|z^{*})KL ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) âˆ¥ italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the actual loss that can be meta-optimized in RAG, in which pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) is the ground truth distribution and pâ¢(r|zâˆ—)ğ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘§p(r|z^{*})italic_p ( italic_r | italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the estimated distribution. As this loss decreases, the value of râ¢(z)ğ‘Ÿğ‘§r(z)italic_r ( italic_z ) when zğ‘§zitalic_z is not equal to zâˆ—superscriptğ‘§z^{*}italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also decreases, which means that in EquationÂ 104, the ratio of the knowledge from LLMsâ€™ pre-trained distribution decreases and meanwhile the ratio of knowledge from the retrieved texts increases. Lower loss means that the output of RAG is closer to the distribution of retrieved texts, which is actually that LLMs learning the distribution from retrieved texts in input context. Since pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) is the ground truth in this learning but dose not have any explicit input-output supervision like demonstrations in in-context learning, RAG is the unsupervised in-context learning and distribution of retrieved texts (pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r )) is the unsupervised learning signal.

Based on the above two perspectives, we successfully prove that: The distribution of retrieved passage rğ‘Ÿritalic_r in RAG (i.e., pRâ¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿp_{R}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r )) can serve as the unsupervised learning signal for LLMs learning from context, even without explicit input-output supervision. RAG is actually unsupervised in-context Learning that fuses the distribution from retrieved texts with LLMsâ€™ pre-trained distribution. âˆ

Appendix H Experimental details

H.1 Baselines

For primary experiment that needs methods to determine the value order between benefit and detriment for each token, it is actually a binary classification task (benefit outweigh detriment or not). The mainstream methods in this area are detecting and comparing the degree of hallucination between tokens generated by LLMs (w/o RAG) and RAG. Below we will describe in detail how we apply these baselines to this task.

Logprobs. Logprobs can indicate the confidence for LLMs in generating the tokensKuhn etÂ al. [2023]. We use the value order between top-1 log-probability of the tokens output by pure LLM and RAG to determine the value order between benefit and detriment for these tokens. If the logprobs of tokens generated by RAG is greater than the logprobs of tokens generated by pure LLM, the benefit outweigh the detriment, otherwise the detriment outweigh the benefit.

Uncertainty. We use Length-normalized EntropyÂ Malinin and Gales [2020] to measure the uncertainty of the tokens generated by pure LLM and RAG respectively. If the uncertainty of tokens generated by RAG is lower than the uncertainty of tokens generated by pure LLM, the benefit outweigh the detriment, otherwise the detriment outweigh the benefit.

Consistency-LexicalÂ Lin etÂ al. [2022]. Consistency-based methods make LLMs perform multiple generations for a question and calculate consistency score among multiple answers. If the consistency score of tokens generated by RAG is greater than the consistency score of tokens generated by pure LLM, the benefit outweigh the detriment, otherwise the detriment outweigh the benefit. Lexical-based consistency means calculating consistency score by lexical-similarity among multiple answers. Since the experiment is at token level, we use the number of tokens that are completely consistent in multiple generations as the consistency score.

Consistency-SemanticÂ Chen etÂ al. [2024]. We followÂ Chen etÂ al. [2024] to use EigenScore to calculate the semantic similarity among hidden states of tokens in multiple generations and use it as the consistency score.

For open-domain Q&A under practical autoregressive generation setting, baselines for this include the methods that introduce additional modules to filter irrelevant passages (NLI+RAGÂ Yoran etÂ al. [2024]) or as action triggers (CRAGÂ Yan etÂ al. [2024]), train more robust LLMs for RAG (RetRobustÂ Yoran etÂ al. [2024] and INFO-RAGÂ Xu etÂ al. [2024a]) and train LLMs to dynamically retrieve and critique retrieved texts (Self-RAGÂ Asai etÂ al. [2023]).

NLI+RAG. This method use a Natural Language Inference model to filter the possible irrelevant documents in retrieved results and provide the remaining documents to LLMs for generation. We followÂ Yoran etÂ al. [2024] to use a BART-Large modelÂ Lewis etÂ al. [2019] with 407 million parameters trained on the MNLI datasetÂ Williams etÂ al. [2017]. We consider a query-document pair as entailed if the probability for the entailment label is â‰¥0.5absent0.5\geq 0.5â‰¥ 0.5 and filter the documents with probability for the entailment label <0.5absent0.5<0.5< 0.5.

CRAG. This method uses a retrieval evaluator to assess the correctness of retrieved texts trigger different actions based on the evaluation results. One of the actions is using additional google search API for web search, which is unfair for baselines and our method. So we remove this action and use its knowledge refinement strategy for document filteringÂ Yan etÂ al. [2024].

RetRobust. This method fine-tunes LLMs to properly leverage retrieved passages with a mix of relevant and irrelevant contextsÂ Yoran etÂ al. [2024].

INFO-RAG. This method uses unsupervised method to make LLMs learn to use the retrieved texts robustly. It enables LLMs to judge the correctness of the retrieved texts, extract the correct content and revise the wrong contentÂ Xu etÂ al. [2024a].

Self-RAG. This method trains LLMs to dynamically retrieve and critique retrieved texts. Self-RAG first decodes a retrieval token to evaluate the utility of retrieval and control a retrieval component. If retrieval is required, LLM calls an external retrieval module to find top relevant documents, using input query and previous generation. If retrieval is not required, LLM continues generation. If retrieval is needed, LLM first generates critique token evaluating whether retrieved documents are relevant and support generation, and then generates continuation conditioned on the retrieved passagesÂ Asai etÂ al. [2023].

H.2 Implementation details

All models are run on a V100 GPU with PytorchÂ Paszke etÂ al. [2019] and accelerated by DeepSpeedÂ 222https://github.com/microsoft/DeepSpeed. As for retrieval for RAG, we followÂ Xu etÂ al. [2023, 2024a] to use ColBERTv2Â Santhanam etÂ al. [2021], an excellent generalizable model as the retriever, and use Wikipedia consisting of 21,015,324 passagesÂ Karpukhin etÂ al. [2020] as retrieval database. All baselines and X-RAG share the same retrieval setup and prompt. We use OPT-6.7B, LLaMA-2-7B and Mistral-7B-v0.1 as LLMs in primary experiment and use greedy-decoding strategy for generation.

Appendix I Case Study

FigureÂ 4 shows the case study for collaborative generation between pure LLM and RAG at token level in our X-RAG. At the step that pure LLM and RAG generates the different tokens, X-RAG use our theoretical results in TheoremÂ 3 to compare the benefit and detriment. If benefit is greater than detriment, the token from RAG is selected, otherwise, the token from pure LLM is selected. The selected tokens are marked by green color and bold. Then discarded tokens are marked by gray. The orange arrow represents the direction of token selection and usage. The selected tokens are used for the next step generation of both pure LLM and RAG. This case study visually demonstrates that our X-RAG effectively enables pure LLM and RAG for collaborative generation to preserve benefit and avoid detriment.
